title: Musée des Beaux-Arts de Bordeaux
text:
The Musée des Beaux-Arts de Bordeaux is the <a href="fine%20arts">fine arts</a> museum of the city of <a href="Bordeaux">Bordeaux</a>, France. The museum is housed in a dependency of the <a href="Palais%20Rohan%2C%20Bordeaux">Palais Rohan</a> in central Bordeaux. Its collections include paintings, sculptures and drawings from the 15th century to the 20th century. The largest collection is composed of paintings, and its strong points are works by <a href="French%20painters">French</a> and <a href="Dutch%20painter">Dutch painter</a>s. 
In front of the building, there is the Galerie des Beaux-Arts, where temporary exhibitions are housed.
History.
Established in 1801 by the painter <a href="Pierre%20Lacour">Pierre Lacour</a>, it is one of the largest art galleries in France outside Paris. The museum holds several paintings that were looted by the French during the <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution</a> (so-called 'saisies révolutionnaires') such as the "Martyrdom of Saint Georges" by <a href="Peter%20Paul%20Rubens">Peter Paul Rubens</a>.
First hosted in a library and then in a room of the town hall, the collection was moved into the current building after its construction from 1875 to 1881. The "Galerie des Beaux-Arts" was built later, from 1936 to 1939.
